content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number. The function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math> is defined on the closed interval <math alttext="open bracket, negative 2 comma 8, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mpadded><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mpadded><mo>,</mo><mn>8</mn></mpadded><mo>]</mo></mpadded></math> and satisfies <math alttext="f of 2 equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>2</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. The graph of <math alttext="f prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></math>, the derivative of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math>, consists of two line segments and a semicircle, as shown in the figure. (a) Does <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math> have a relative minimum, a relative maximum, or neither at <math alttext="x equals 6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number. The function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math> is defined on the closed interval <math alttext="open bracket, negative 2 comma 8, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mpadded><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mpadded><mo>,</mo><mn>8</mn></mpadded><mo>]</mo></mpadded></math> and satisfies <math alttext="f of 2 equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>2</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. The graph of <math alttext="f prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></math>, the derivative of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math>, consists of two line segments and a semicircle, as shown in the figure. (a) Does <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math> have a relative minimum, a relative maximum, or neither at <math alttext="x equals 6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.
(b) On what open intervals, if any, is the graph of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math> concave down? Give a reason for your answer.

(c) Find the value of <math alttext="the limit as x approaches 2, of, the fraction with numerator 6 times f of x, minus 3 x, and denominator x squared, minus 5 x, plus 6, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mn>6</mn><mspace width="0.15em"></mspace><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>,</mo></math> or show that it does not exist. Justify your answer.

(d) Find the absolute minimum value of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math> on the closed interval <math alttext="open bracket, negative 2 comma 8, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mpadded><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mpadded><mo>,</mo><mn>8</mn></mpadded><mo>]</mo></mpadded></math>. Justify your answer.

topic.text: 4.7: Using L'Hospital's Rule for Determining Limits of Indeterminate Forms

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Identify mathematical information from graphical, numerical, analytical, and/or verbal representations.
